snippet: Erratic driving by returning troops is being identified as a symptom of traumatic brain injury or post-traumatic stress disorder — and coming under greater scrutiny.
abstract: Erratic driving by returning combat veterans is being identified as a symptom of traumatic brain injury or post-traumatic stress disorder, and is coming under greater scrutiny amid higher accident rates among veterans; in a review of driving records for tens of thousands of troops before and after deployments, USAA, a leading insurer of active-duty troops, discovered that auto accidents in which the service members were at fault went up by 13 percent after deployments; research and education are being expanded to help curtail the problem.
lead_paragraph: Erratic driving by returning troops is being identified as a symptom of traumatic brain injury or post-traumatic stress disorder — and coming under greater scrutiny.

headline.seo: Help Available for Drivers Who Have Wartime Trauma
headline.main: Back From War, Fear and Danger Fill Driver’s Seat
headline.print_headline: Back From War, Fear and Danger Fill Driver’s Seat
